content.description:
Treehouse is fun, flowy, and has a great view into Bear Canyon. Begin at the far left of the boulder (before it drops down towards

Hanging Garden

), and start sitting down with a left hand edge in a little corner and your right hand on another down-pulling edge. I do two hand movements before reaching a left handed jug. From here, you reach out right to a vertical crack, match it, and then go up to jugs.

It's about 10-12 feet to the lip, but I think it's fun to climb the slab all the way to the top of the boulder...just be careful. To get down, I hop off near the jugs at the lip.

If I am wrong about getting the first ascent, please reach out, and I'll update.
content.location: If you are looking at Dinosaur Rock from the Mallory Cave trail, continue upwards along the trail till you're near the top of the formation. Head towards the top of Dino Rock, and you should see a very large boulder to the right of it. Follow along the left side of the boulder (you are walking between Dinosaur Rock and this large boulder) and at the end of it, before a drop off, you'll see Treehouse.

content.description: Start low, establishing on decent holds. Do a one move wonder up and right to the obvious pebble, and top out.
content.location:
It is downhill from the

V12 dyno problem

on the same rock.

content.description: Dino’s Dyno is one of, if not the coolest, pure dyno boulder problem in the Boulder area. Start standing under the trail on a left hand, weird sloper and right hand undercling or sidepull. Pull on with difficulty, and with some awkward feet, punch 4 feet to a perfect pair of comfy edges, the right hand being better. Some do this move with 1 hand, some with 2, either way it’s hard, and avoiding a dab can be problematic. The second move is either another massive dyno to a left sloper jug which is said to be easier than the first, but it felt much harder. It’s a style thing I guess. It’s possible to work around right then back left using some horrible holds, which avoids the dyno but isn’t any easier. Top out carefully. Satisfying movement and a few sweet moves make this a perfect choice for the V12 power climber.
content.location: Once at Dinosaur Rock, continue up the Mallory Cave Trail. The overhanging boulder is just off to the right side of the trail about 5 minutes past the Flatiron. Dino’s Dyno is in the center of the large face.

content.description:
Hanging Garden sort of...hangs above the ground, which makes pulling on a little tricky. Stacking some pads helps. Start with your right hand on a thin sidepull and your left hand on a pinch on the arete. To get my feet high enough to start climbing, I pushed off of the boulder that is underneath and to the left; this allows me to get my right foot smeared onto the actual problem. Once on, I release the left foot and begin.

The first move is the hardest, you have to pretty accurately grab a thin/sharp crimp with your right hand. The rest of the moves aren't too bad, but the last move requires some confidence. Your position feels a bit airy, so having a spotter and some pads would be wise. To finish, after matching the jug crack, I climbed onto the boulder to the left and continued till I was able to downclimb, which I thought was fun.

I am not sure about the grade, as I'm the only one to have climbed it, but I'd imagine it's between V4-6. If anyone sees this and wants more beta/location info, reach out.
content.location:
If you're at Dinosaur Mountain, continue up the trail passing the sport climbs on the left (

Ultrasaurus

, etc.) You will continue till you're at the top of Dinosaur Mountain. At this point, move up and left, and you'll get to a really big boulder quite close to the top of Dinosaur Mountain. Hanging Garden is directly on the other side of the boulder and sort of...beneath it. If you scramble your way around to the right and then down, you'll find it.
